review_blob: Golden-amber coloured beer, strongly carbonated, with big three-finger white head. Aromas are toffee, polished wood, pear, cumin. Taste is basically dry, but with big burnt caramel background adding weight and bitterness. Some fruit sweetness at the end.
Very slightly cloudy, golden coloured beer with two-finger white head. Aromas are honey, apple, fruit esters. Some white bread maltiness and sweetness in the taste, but ends with a dry finish.

Highly-carbonated pour gives four-finger coarse white head on top of pale straw coloured beer. Aromas are straw, honey, grass, lemon, yeast cake. Taste is herbal-dry but well-balanced with a honey component.

Bottle pour of a golden straw-coloured, highly-carbonated ale. Two-finger white head. Lemongrass, mandarin, and dry pine aromas. Dry with modest bittering for the style. Typical Citra finish, but kept at moderate levels to avoid pushing this low abv pale into hop-piss territory. Well-made.

Pours a chestnut brown beer with one-finger ivory white head. Aromas of toffee, spice, and hop earthiness. Strong malt caramels and toffees from start to finish without being too sweet. Slightly sharp, sudden hop bittering at the end. Very drinkable without having any unique character.

Pours a golden yellow, slightly cloudy beer with a one-finger smooth white head. Aroma is restrained citrus sweetness and malt toffee character. Taste has hints of malt roast in addition to the toffee / caramel. Good malt complexity for the abv, with firm earthy hop-bittering for the style. Solid beer, could drink a few, and interesting enough for those willing to look past the standard hop profile.

Bottle pours out a clear chestnut beer with two-finger beige head. Many components in the aroma: red berries, cherry drops, some esters, dry coffee beans, chocolate, toffee, some pine or grass. Full mouthfeel leads into a malty but bitter finish.

Pours clear deep mahogany red with one-finger beige head. Aroma is mango, almost banana, some grass. Restrained malt body, without any of the darker malt character that might be expected. Finishes with some bread sweetness under the hop aromas noted above. Pleasant enough.
Golden pour, somewhat cloudy due to particulates. Thin head. Aroma is oranges and pine. Dry finish.

Golden straw yellow, slightly cloudy, with two-finger tight white head. Aroma is not grapefruit for me, more mango dominated by menthol and resin. Good though. Some pear esters? Fairly strong bread malt start to the taste, before an oily, resinuous bitter finish. Great IPA.

Pours light straw yellow with high carbonation giving a three-finger pure white coarse head with excellent persistence. Aroma is quite restrained - honey and lemon cough sweets, cooking apples, and lime sweetness. Good, initially oily, mouth feels drops away to give a crisp dry finish. Almost tart.

Pours a chestnut red, very clear, with one-finger coarse white head that is extremely persistent. Aroma is mango, ripe nectarines, resin, grass, basically Robinsons tropical fruit juice drink with hints of mint or menthol. Impressive. In comparison the taste seems slightly thin. Finish is neither sweet nor dry but somehow neutral. A bit disappointing, even for a low gravity beer. Many boring brown beers have more malt action going on in the back than this. Still a very good session beer though.

Bottle pours an deep orange, amber beer with a one-finger white head. Aroma is caramel and brioche bread on the malt side, with hop components of black current and pine. Moderately full body going into somewhat sweet finish.

Pours chestnut brown, murky, with one-finger coarse beige head. Aroma is green apples, pear drops, bread crusts, maybe red cherry and raisin. Taste starts with plum, then some alcohol but fairly restrained. Very good but not as complex or spectacular as Id expected.

Black pour, mahogany around the edges, with thin one-finger cappucino-coloured head. Aromas of treacle, molasses, espresso, dark cherry jam, walnuts, some alcohol. Taste just as complex. Sticky and bitter finish leaves barrel character in the mouth. A bit mental.
A cloudy straw-coloured pour with very thin head. The aroma is relatively weak - oranges, bread, grass or hay, some weak clove character. Taste is pleasantly dry, with a powerful spicey finish.
Pours golden, slightly cloudy, with a two-finger open head. Aroma is honey, basil, brioche, cinnamon. On tasting, the hop character is herbal and spicy. Dry finish. Just a hint of alcohol.

Pale amber pour with two-finger open-pored white head. Aroma is honey, cloves, bread, and hop floral character. Taste is dry. High carbonation. Hop bitterness and notable spice and liquorice on the finish. Very well balanced.

A golden beer, very slightly cloudy, with one-finger white head. Orange, melon, perhaps mint, perhaps soap in a moderately sweet and moderately strong aroma. Mouthfeel thin to moderate. Bittering comes towards the finish, and is moderate. Overall, a well-balanced, interesting-enough session beer.

Bottle pours a chesnut beer, with moderate carbonation and one-finger white head. Aromas are toffee-like, almost roasty, malts and juicy fruit hop character. Taste is shifted more towards the caramel malts than most beers of this style. The bittering is restrained.

Bottle pours a cloudy amber-coloured beer with a two-finger, white, and coarse head. Aroma is mandarins, pine, wax, some hop herbal character and candy sugar. Low carbonation for the style. Taste starts with a bitter pinch on the tongue, then a full malt sweetness. Ends with bitter orange marmalade and hop citrus. More floral than mosy IPAs.

Pours black and opaque, with three-finger, beige, coarse-grained head. Aroma of sweet chocolate malt and fresh manure (better than it sounds). Taste is roasted malt bitterness or acidity. Some hop fruit character.

Bottle pours a cloudy straw-coloured beer with three-finger white head. Aroma is freshly slice mandarins and cereal malt notes. Taste starts with good body but fairly neutral malt character. In the finish there is bitterness and citrus. Balanced and sessionable.

Bottle pour of clear amber ale. Two-finger white head dissipates within five minutes. Some hop floral and spice character in the aroma. Thin body, dry due to strong hop bittering for the style. Slightly grape-like, with some malt caramel towards the finish.

Bottle pours clear deep amber beer. Two-finger cream head dissipates within a minute or so. Aroma is mild - light toffee notes, some apple, with hop floral character. Taste is light caramel malt, some stewed hop bitterness.

Bottle pours golden-syrup coloured beer under a two-finger white head. Slightly cloudy. Hop aroma is partly green citrus, some orange too, and mostly pine. Oily mouth feel. Not much malt character on tasting. The hop components are strong but broad enough to avoid being too one-dimensional.

Bottle pours a deep chestnut, ruby brown beer with a pillowy beige three-finger head. Aroma is dark chocolate, leather, dark red fruits, and quite present herbal hop notes. Taste first mixes liquorice with punchy hop bitterness, before a dry coca powder bomb goes off. Dry finish calls for more. Good.

Bottle pours an orange, slightly cloudy beer. One-finger white head. Aroma is white grapes, orange peel, green leaves, and hop floral character. Almost minty or spicy. Moderate malt sweetness gives way to strong but blunt bitterness and an interesting smoke note. Nice.

Bottle pours clear mahogany beer underneath off-white one-finger head. Aromas of dark cherries, cocoa, bubblegum, roses, and grass. Taste is dry, with noticeable bittering on the finish. More like a bitter with a dark malt bill than a genuine mild, but drinkable and enjoyable nonetheless.

Pours clear chestnut brown, highly carbonated with two-finger white head. Aroma of dark toffee, molasses, strawberry, some hop floral or earthy notes. Taste is surprisingly clean at first, bittering gives way to sweet malt caramels and toffees, dark fruits, some alcohol, liquorice, and clove spices.

Pours dark amber, one-finger beige head, with relatively high carbonation from the bottle. Huge aroma of mango, grapefruit, resin, burnt toffee. Taste is then surprisingly dry, with strong bittering. Malt toasts and toffee comes out. Complex but balanced. Reputation deserved.

Pale straw pour. Thin white head dissipates within a minute or so. Clove, spice, apple, and almonds in the aroma. Some hop floral components too. Taste is clean, dry, again with some spice. Very refreshing. An excellent and interesting beer, would be perfect with a curry.

Bottle pours chesnut orange with two-finger white head. Aroma is toffee and bread notes from the malt,maybe liquorice, balanced with earthy and spicy hop character. Also some cut-grass component. Taste punches in a moderate bitterness at first, before fading quickly to slightly sweet caramel maltiness. Certainly very good, but perhaps overrated outside the UK?

Draught. Pale straw colour with one-finger white head. Green fruit and associated acidity dominate the aroma. Moderate but short-lived bitterness provide good drinkability. Solid example of a light refreshing summer british ale.

After deep mahogany-brown pour with almost no head, strong liquorice and caramel aroma. Taste is similar, some additional herbals from somewhere, with dry finish that includes bitterness from a roasted malt. High carbonation. Complex, unhinged, nice.
Cask. Dark copper in colour. Some hop floral character. Toffee malt taste, almost bitter, like burnt toffee or liquorice. Quite thin on the palate, but this makes it highly sessionable.
beer_name: Shepherd Neame Whitstable Bay Pale Ale (Cask)

review_blob: Crystal clear, straw yellow with three-finger white head and active CO2 release. Yeasty aroma with strong herbal hop components like sage and juniper. Taste is a bread maltiness. Sweet, low bittering but somr herbal hop notes as above. A bit one-dimensional to live up to the reputation.
Pours mahogany with one-finger off-white head. Aroma contains toffee and apple. Initially quite acrid in the mouth, but then comes a dominant malt roast and almost floral hop bitterness.

One-finger white head that thins quickly. Golden orange clear body. Aroma is caramel and burnt toffee. Very sweet. Perhaps a hint of herbal hop character. Flavour is a battle between firm, almost metallic, hop bittering and the malt factors noted in the aroma. Nice low carbonation. Finishes quite dry, but nonetheless a bit too buttery sweet to be a favourite for me.

Ivory-white head pours on top of deep ruby red, slightly cloudy, beer. Dominant aroma is esters, pears, green fruit. Also some malt character, perhaps a light to medium caramel, and a hop vegetal component. The esters are there on tasting, but sit behind a complex malt ensemble: roast malt, burnt toffee, and liquorice. Quite a sweet finish, but the 9% alcohol is well hidden. Will drink again.

Big three-finger white pours onto golden clear body and stays as long as the beer lasts. Aroma is pepper, cloves, chlorine sweetness, some banana, some pear. Taste is fairly sweet until the aftertaste, which is actually quite dry. Good body for a pale-coloured ale.

Pours deep brown if not black, with one-finger beige head. Aroma is roasted cake crust, chocolate, bubblegum, cherries. A reasonably firm bitterness balances the same components in the taste. Some hop floral character. Creamy mouthfeel.

Pours a two-finger white head on top of a somewhat cloudy, mahogany coloured body. Aroma is yeasty, malt caramels, and some hop menthol character. On tasting the phenols are present but restrained enough to allow some hop bittering to close out a dry finish. Fairly high carbonation. Nice.
Pours clear Ribena red with one-finger persistent pink head. Smell is dominated by sour cherry. Hard to pick up anything else. Sweetness in the taste is balanced by tart dry finish.

One-finger head on top of chesnut brown body. Slightly cloudy. Aroma is malt fruitiness, some apples and toffee. Taste contains a hop bittering which punches through the malt character at the end. Very well balanced and moreish.

Deep amber, clear, with one-finger white head. Sweet buttery aroma. Taste is strongly malty, plenty of vanilla and butter. Too sweet for me, but that might be the style. Also not sure if the butter is coming from the barrel or the fermentation.

Golden, almost clear with thin white head. Aroma contains mango, fruity character and some grass. Taste is cereal malt, only light bittering, and just faint hints of the fruti in aromas. Not bad but a bit bland.

Mahogany brown with off-white head that disappeared within a minute on this pour. Strong pear drops aroma, some spice, some crystalline sweetness. Taste adds a malt liquorice component, and emphasizes phenols. Light carbonation.

Pours dark mahogany brown with three-finger beige head. Aroma is piney hops, some sweet caramel malts. Taste is well-balanced between aa strong hop bitterness, some cherry fruit, a bitterness coming from the darker malts, some roast character approaching something like dark brown bread crust. Hop bitterness lingers long on the the tongue. Highly drinkable for the ABV.

Pours clear amber brown with one-finger white head that vanishes quite quickly. Smell of strong malt sweetness, some peppery phenols and a quite medicinal component. Taste is thick, sweet, and spicy with some hot alcohol.
